newsitem.title: USA: Conn. may get $3.6 bln in tobacco case - report.
newsitem.headline: Conn. may get $3.6 bln in tobacco case - report.

text.p: Connecticut would receive about $129 million this year -- and a total of $3.6 billion over 25 years -- under a proposed tobacco settlement being considered by Congress, the state's legal chief said in a newspaper interview published Tuesday.
Attorney General Richard Blumenthal told the Hartford Courant that half the money received by the state would have to be spent on health insurance for uninsured children.
This was in keeping with an agreement negotiated between tobacco companies and attorneys general for 40 states, Blumenthal said.
The other half of the settlement, or nearly $65 million in the first year, could be used however the state saw fit -- including tax cuts, Blumenthal said.

The landmark agreement rerquires tobacco firms to pay the states some $368 billion over 25 years to offset the effects of smoking. The agreement also puts unprecedented government limits on the way cigarettes are advertised and sold.
The agreement requires Congressional approval, which is not a certainty, as well as President Bill Clinton's signature.
Blumenthal predicted that the agreement would be adopted in some form.
Blumenthal, a Democrat, was one of five attorneys general who led negotiations that resulted in the June 20 settlement.

He said it was likely that Connecticut would receive about 1.8 percent of the total payments made by tobacco companies to the 50 states. This translates to an upfront payment of $129.2 million as soon as Congress gives the go-ahead, and annual payments starting at $73.9 million thereafter, Blumenthal said.
The annual payment to Connecticut would peak at $147.7 million in 2003, he said.

The windfall due Connecticut is greater than a ballyhooed settlement reached last week by Mississippi, but it comes with a catch, Blumenthal said. It is contingent on approval by the president and Congress of a national settlement.
If there is no national settlement, "Connecticut would be in much the same position (as Mississippi) in negotiating its own figure with the tobacco companies directly," Blumenthal said.
